020package org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.vendor;
021
022import org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.StringOption;
023
024/**
025 * <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4833">RFC 4833</a> defines new timezone options for DHCPv4. Use PCode class
026 * together with {@link TCode} instead of deprecated {@link org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.vendor.TimeOffset
027 * TimeOffset} . <br>
028 * <br>
029 * POSIX provides a standard for how to express timezone information in a character string. However, for accuracy over
030 * longer periods that involve daylight- saving rule changes or other irregular changes, a more detailed mechanism is
031 * necessary. <br>
032 * <br>
033 * The <a href="http://www.twinsun.com/tz/tz-link.htm">TZ Database</a> that is used in many operating systems provides
034 * backwards consistency and accuracy for almost all real-world locations since 1970. The TZ database also attempts to
035 * provide a stable set of human readable timezone identifiers. <br>
036 * <br>
037 * TZ POSIX string is a string suitable for the TZ variable as specified by section 8.3 of POSIX standard, with the
038 * exception that a string may not begin with a colon (":"). This string is NOT terminated by an ASCII NULL. Here is an
039 * example: <br>
040 * <br>
041 * EST5EDT4,M3.2.0/02:00,M11.1.0/02:00
042 *
043 * @author marekgr
044 * @see <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4833#section-4">RFC 4833 (section 4)</a>
045 */
046public class PCode extends StringOption {
047
048    private static final short TAG = 100;
049
050    public PCode() {
051    }
052
053    /**
054     * @param tZPOSIXString
055     *            TZ POSIX String
056     */
057    public PCode(String tZPOSIXString) {
058        setStringValue(tZPOSIXString);
059    }
060
061    /*
062     * @see org.apache.directory.server.dhcp.options.DhcpOption#getTag()
063     */
064    @Override
065    public byte getTag() {
066        return TAG;
067    }
068}
